Centre Hospitalier de l'Université de Montréal (CHUM)

body_text.text: The Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a pandemic caused by severe acute 2 respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) [1] that infected 3,524,429 patients and 3 was linked to 247,838 deaths worldwide, as of May 4, 2020 [2] . SARS-CoV-2 infection is 4 triggered by binding to angiotensin-converting enzyme-2 (ACE2), which is highly expressed 5 in the nasopharynx and lungs, as well as in the cardiovascular system and gastrointestinal and 23 We reviewed the published literature (including multiple search strategies in 1 MEDLINE with PubMed interface) and critically assessed early reports on medRxiv 2 (https://www.medrxiv.org/). An electronic search was executed employing the keywords 3 "cardiovascular" OR "cardiac" OR "heart" AND "coronavirus 2019" OR "COVID-19" OR 4 "SARS-CoV-2", between 2019 and May 4, 2020. No language restrictions were applied. The 5 title, abstract and full text of all articles captured with these search criteria were assessed. 6 Social media (Twitter, LinkedIn, and Facebook) were also consulted. 7 In such times, methodologically-sound research on COVID-19 and its cardiovascular 8 manifestations is hampered by numerous challenges. These include SARS-CoV-2 test 9 availability and accuracy, the decision of healthcare authorities not to screen for infection 10 certain groups (which could lead to underestimation of the pandemic burden), heterogeneous 11 reporting across countries, as well as the fact that estimates of the exact incidence of specific 12 COVID-19 complications and prevalence of baseline comorbidities are often being carried out 13 in a suboptimal fashion (e.g., small single-center cohorts, isolated reports on social media, 14 etc). For all these limitations, a high degree of caution and criticism should be adopted to 15 identify selective reporting and biased data, and when drawing conclusions based on small 16 case series or anecdotal case reports.

Epidemiology 20 SARS-CoV-2 is transmitted between people through respiratory droplets and fomites. 21 The basic reproduction number (R 0 : the number of cases one infected individual can infect on 22 average) of SARS-CoV-2 ranges from 2.2 to 3.2 [8] . However, to understand the full epidemic 23 potential of SARS-CoV-2, it is necessary to take into consideration the high fraction (up to 24 86% of cases) of undocumented infections (asymptomatic or mild symptoms) that remains 1 unrecognized and could expose a far greater portion of the population to the virus [9] . The 2 case fatality rate of COVID-19 widely varies across countries, ranging from 0.3% to 3 7.2% [10, 11] . 14 It has been speculated that some drugs could increase susceptibility to developing 15 severe forms of COVID-19. Patients with pre-existing cardiovascular disease, receiving ARB 16 or ACEI have an upregulation of ACE2, which would be therefore available in great amounts 17 to offer a binding site for SARS-CoV-2[3,4,24]. However, this concern, derived from in-vitro 18 and animal studies, has not found confirmation in clinical practice [24] . Indeed, in a large One possible mechanism of acute myocardial injury caused by SARS-CoV-2 infection 23 could be its affinity to ACE2, which is widely expressed in the heart, and cause direct 24 myocardial injury [5, 17] . Other proposed pathways include a cytokine storm triggered by an 1 imbalanced response by type 1 and type 2 T-helper cells[5], sympathetic hyperactivity, 2 anemia and hypoxemic myocardial cells damage due to respiratory dysfunction (type 2 MI). In a small meta-analysis (4 studies, 341 patients), standardized mean differences of 10 cardiac troponin I levels were significantly higher in those with severe COVID-19-related 11 symptoms compared to those with non-severe presentation [28] . Myocardial injury, present in 12 19.7% of COVID-19 patients, was associated with higher levels of inflammatory biomarkers, 13 more severe pulmonary involvement, higher need for non-invasive and invasive ventilation, In a series reporting on 68 deaths in a cohort of 150 COVID-19 patients, 7% were 23 attributed to myocarditis with hemodynamic collapse, while in 33% of cases myocarditis 24 could have played a contributing role to patient death [31] . Although the clinical picture is still 1 referred to as a "myocarditis" in many instances, myocardial infection by SARS-CoV-2 was 2 not proven in most cases with COVID-19 myocardial involvement. To date, only isolated case 3 reports provided data on the pathology of the myocardial tissue from COVID-19 patients,

Early mortality was 39.3%. Interestingly, angiography demonstrated the absence of 22 obstructive coronary artery disease in 39.3% of cases, a finding also reported in the US by 23 Bangalore et al. [40] , who found non-obstructive disease in one-third of the patients who 24 underwent coronary angiography. In this latter series, the prognosis of STEMI presentation 1 was even worse than in the previous report, with a 72% in-hospital mortality rate.

In addition to type 2 MI, "myocarditis" and stress cardiomyopathy, microvascular 3 thrombosis has also been hypothesized as a mechanism underlying certain cases mimicking 4 STEMI presentation without obstructive coronary artery disease, given the endothelial 5 dysfunction and hypercoagulable state associated with COVID-19. Table 2 . The potential for artificial intelligence (AI) to assist in pandemic modeling and in the 6 diagnosis of COVID-19 clinical manifestations is immense. While epidemiologists and public 7 health officials cannot be replaced, AI can serve to gather and systematically organize rapidly 8 evolving information (e.g., from social media and news media) to assist officials in decision-9 making[84]. Moreover, AI is particularly suited for massive analysis of imaging data, which 10 at the moment has been taken advantage of for COVID-19 pneumonitis diagnosis[85] but is 11 also potentially suitable for cardiac applications, such as automated interpretation of 12 electrocardiograms, imaging, and pathology specimens. The COVID-19 pandemic represents the most important public health crisis of the 16 century. The health, economic, and societal impacts will be felt for many years to come.
Common symptoms: fever, dry cough, dyspnea, myalgias, fatigue, diarrhea, anosmia, dysgeusia.
Uncommon symptoms: sputum production, headache, hemoptysis, rhinorrhea, sore throat, conjunctival injection.
Lymphopenia; prolonged prothrombin time; elevated D-dimer, alanine aminotransferase, total bilirubin and lactate dehydrogenase
PaO2/FiO2 <200 if acute respiratory distress syndrome
Generally bilateral pneumonia with multiple infiltrates and ground-grass opacity
Real-time polymerase-chain reaction (RT-PCR) assay to detect viral RNA Abbreviations: FiO2, fraction of inspired oxygen; PaO2, partial pressure of oxygen.

-COVID-19 testing -Telemedicine -Rationalization of indications for diagnostic and therapeutic procedures -Conservative management as first-line strategy whenever possible -Minimize the number of providers per procedure -Contact and droplet precautions (gown, face mask, eye protection, gloves) for general care -N95 mask and face shield (or PAPR), waterproof gown, and gloves for aerosol-generating procedures -Surgical mask for patients with known or suspected COVID-19 -Education Cardiopulmonary resuscitation -Use of external mechanical compression devices to minimize direct contact with infected patients -Close coordination with critical care and anesthesia teams for airway management Catheterization laboratory environment -Switch to negative pressure (if possible) -Intubation prior to transfer to the catheterization laboratory (if required) Specific consideration to subspecialty care teams -Separation of individuals with overlapping skillsets to guarantee continued availability of care in case of COVID-19 infection within the team Abbreviations: PAPR, powered air-purifying respirator.

FIGREF0.text: symptoms usually dominate the clinical presentation of COVID-8 19, SARS-CoV-2 infection might also be responsible for a variety of potentially severe 9 cardiovascular manifestations, particularly in patients with pre-existing cardiovascular 10 conditions[4-6]. Indeed, subjects with cardiovascular diseases do suffer worse outcomes 11 when infected with SARS-CoV-2[5]. Moreover, COVID-19 could have an indirect impact on 12 the delivery of cardiovascular care (both in patients with and without COVID-19), by 13 reducing the efficiency of existing pathways (e.g., primary percutaneous coronary 14 intervention [PCI] networks, intensive care unit [ICU] bed availability, etc.)[7], and through 15 decreased utilization of healthcare services by patients, due to concern of acquiring in-hospital 16 infection. 17 This article provides a comprehensive overview of the pathophysiology and 18 cardiovascular implications of COVID-19, its impact on existing pathways of care, the role of 19 modern technologies to tackle the pandemic, and a proposal of novel management algorithms 20 for the most common acute cardiac conditions.

FIGREF3.text: illustrates the pathophysiology of SARS-CoV-2 infection. Severe clinical 7 presentations are generally associated with rapid viral replication, infiltration of inflammatory 8 cells and exaggerated release of cytokines (cytokine release syndrome), leading to multiorgan 9 damage, including an acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)[12,13]. Patients requiring 10 ICU admission have higher serum levels of granulocyte colony-stimulating factor, 11 granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor, interferon-inducible protein-10, monocyte 12 chemoattractant protein-1, macrophage inflammatory protein-1A, and tumor necrosis factor 13 (TNF)-α [6], further suggesting that the "intensity" of the "cytokine storm" modulates the 14 severity of the disease. Interestingly, dramatically increased plasma interleukin (IL)-6 levels 15 have been reported in SARS-CoV-2-infected patients with myocardial injury[6]. 16 Myocardial manifestations might be related to a stress cardiomyopathy or cytokine-17 related myocardial dysfunction that occurs in the setting of severe forms of COVID-19 and 18 mimics the syndromes observed in secondary haemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis and 19 macrophage activation syndrome, which are characterized by a fulminant and fatal cytokine 20 release[14]. These unique features of COVID-19 pathophysiology might open a door for the 21 treatment of severe forms of this infection by means of immune response modulation therapy.

FIGREF5.text: Furthermore, diabetes and dyslipidemia, highly prevalent in this subset of patients, also9 represent markers of immunological dysregulation impacting on COVID-19 infection 10 susceptibility and outcomes[4,24]. As previously reported with other viral infections 11 particularly influenza), COVID-19 might increase the occurrence of adverse cardiovascular 12 events and induce acute exacerbation of chronic conditions such as ischemic heart disease or 13 chronic heart failure[24].

FIGREF6.text: 19multinational cohort of 8,910 COVID-19 patients, Mehra et al.[25]  did not observe an 20 increase in the risk of in-hospital death associated with the use of ACEI (2.1% vs. 6.1%; odds 21 ratio 0.33, 95% confidence interval 0.20-0.54) or ARB (6.8% vs. 5.7%; odds ratio 1.23, 95%22 confidence interval 0.87-1.74). Similarly, in a large population-based study from Northern 23 Italy, the use of ACEI and ARB was more frequent among patients with Covid-19 than 24 among controls because of their higher prevalence of cardiovascular disease. However, there 25 was no evidence that such drugs affected the risk of COVID-19. [26]. Furthermore, Reynolds 1 et al.[27] found no substantial increase in the likelihood of a positive test for COVID-19 or in 2 the risk of severe COVID-19 presentations in association with five common classes of 3 antihypertensive drugs (ACEI, ARB, beta-blockers, calcium-channel blockers and thiazide 4 diuretics). Therefore, given the balance of pros and cons of withholding such drugs, 5 professional societies have warned against discontinuation of ACEIs and ARBs, as it could 6 paradoxically lead to increased mortality related to the exacerbation of cardiovascular and 7 renal conditions[4,24].

FIGREF7.text: , older adults may also receive non-cardiovascular medications such as non-9 steroid anti-inflammatory drugs and may require insulin or secretagogues for diabetes10 mellitus. These drugs notoriously alter salt and water handling, particularly in the presence of11 impaired renal function, and may worsen respiratory complications, including pulmonary 12 edema and consequent hypoxia[24].

FIGREF8.text: illustrates the different cardiovascular manifestations associated with COVID-19 16 and Figure 3 outlines the evaluation and management algorithms for the most common 17 scenarios.

FIGREF9.text: is detected by an increased troponin level and can be due to 20 myocardial ischemia or non-ischemic myocardial injury, including myocarditis. Use of the 21 Fourth Universal Definition of Myocardial Infarction (MI) is recommended for diagnosis[4].

FIGREF11.text: Chinese reports estimated that myocardial injury occurs in 7-20% of hospitalized4 COVID-19 patients[4]. Myocardial injury associated with SARS-CoV-2 occurred in 5 of the 5 first 41 COVID-19 patients (12.2%) in Wuhan, revealed by an increase in high-sensitivity 6 cardiac troponin I levels (>28 pg/ml)[6]. In this study, 4 of 5 (80%) patients with myocardial 7 injury were admitted to the ICU, which suggests the serious prognostic implications of 8 myocardial injury in patients with COVID-19[6].

FIGREF13.text: 14 and increased rates of ARDS, acute kidney injury and coagulation disorders[29]. Patients with 15 myocardial injury were at higher risk of death[29]. 16 It is hence reasonable to perform an initial measurement of serum troponin upon 17 admission for SARS-CoV-2 infection, as well as longitudinal monitoring during hospital 18 stay[30]. This in turn could identify high-risk individuals who might be the target of advanced 19 therapies (including immune response modulation strategies).

FIGREF15.text: 4which preclude drawing definitive conclusions on this topic[32,33]. Sala et al.[32]  reported on5 a 43-year-old woman with COVID-19 who presented with a reverse Tako-Tsubo syndrome 6 and mild left ventricular systolic dysfunction. Cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) revealed 7 diffuse myocardial edema on the basal and mid left ventricular segments, with no detectable 8 scar. Endomyocardial biopsy documented diffuse T-lymphocytic inflammatory infiltrates and 9 huge interstitial edema without any other substantial damage. Molecular analysis showed 10 absence of the SARS-CoV-2 genome within the myocardium[32]. Tavazzi et al.[33] described 11 for the first time a biopsy-proven myocardial localization of viral particles in a COVID-19 12 patient presenting with cardiogenic shock. Although the clinical presentation suggested severe 13 and necrotizing acute myocarditis, the pathology report demonstrated only low-grade 14 myocardial inflammation and absence of myocyte necrosis[33]. Importantly, SARS-CoV-2 15 was only demonstrated in interstitial cytopathic macrophages and their surroundings, while no 16 viral particle was found in cardiac myocytes, which showed non-specific damage (mainly 17 focal myofibrillar lysis)[33]. Either transient viremia or infected macrophage migration from 18 the lung might occur in COVID-19 patients with non-acute myocardial involvement. The 19 available data seem to rule out a classic myocarditis presentation (i.e., direct infection of 20 myocardial cells by the virus), while they suggest that myocardial involvement in COVID-19 21 might rather be due to the cytokine release syndrome. 22 CMR availability issues, coupled with the potential for in-hospital spread of the virus 23 related to the logistics of performing such test, hampers the utilization of this valuable 24 imaging modality. In this context, endomyocardial biopsy could provide key insights, whereas 1 bedside echocardiography could give information on left ventricular function. 2 No consensus exists on the appropriate treatment of myocarditis associated with 3 COVID-19. In addition to mechanical circulatory support, antiviral therapy (lopinavir-4 ritonavir), immunoglobulin and methylprednisolone were successfully used in the 5 management of some case reports of fulminant myocarditis[34,35]. 6 Pericardial effusion remains an uncommon finding in the literature, and few cases of 7 tamponade in the setting of COVID-19 have been reported[36,37].

FIGREF16.text: al.[38] previously demonstrated that patients with acute respiratory 11 infections were at increased risk for subsequently developing acute MI after both influenza 12 and non-influenza viral illnesses, including other coronavirus species. COVID-19 might 13 trigger an intense inflammatory response which could also increase the risk of coronary 14 plaque rupture. 15 The actual prevalence of acute coronary syndromes (ACS) in the setting of COVID-19 16 infection is unknown, given the gaps in testing witnessed in numerous countries in the early 17 phases of the pandemic, particularly in the absence of typical symptoms suggesting COVID-18 19 infection. 19 In 28 Italian STEMI patients with COVID-19, Stefanini et al.[39] reported that STEMI 20 represented the first clinical manifestation of COVID-19 in the majority of cases (85.7%).

FIGREF17.text: hospitalized COVID-19 patients, cardiac arrhythmias represented the leading 9 complication (19.6%) and were more common in patients requiring ICU admission (44.4% vs.

FIGREF18.text: .Guo et al.[41]  revealed that in 187 COVID-19 positive patients stratified by the11 level of troponin, malignant ventricular arrhythmias was twice more frequent in the presence 12 of elevated troponin levels (11.5% vs. 5.2%). Ventricular arrhythmias might also represent the13 first clinical manifestation of SARS-CoV-2 infection. 14 In 136 COVID-19 patients who experienced in-hospital cardiac arrest, Shao et al.[42] 15 revealed that the most common initial rhythm was asystole in 89.7% of cases. Pulseless 16 electrical activity was found in 4.4%, while a shockable rhythm was identified in only 5.9% 17 of patients. 18 In the context of lockdown and overwhelmed healthcare systems unable to provide 19 timely emergency responses, sudden cardiac death has been reported in patients with initially 20 mild symptoms who were later found dead at home while in quarantine[16]. In 4 Italian 21 provinces, Baldi et al.[43] reported an increase of 58% in out-of-hospital cardiac arrest during 22 the 40 days of the COVID-19 outbreak in comparison with the same period in 2019.

FIGREF19.text: Moreover, the cumulative incidence of out-of-hospital cardiac arrest in 2020 was strongly 24 associated with the cumulative incidence of COVID-19, and the increase in the number of1 cases over the number in 2019 followed the time course of the COVID-19 outbreak[43].2In the setting of COVID-19, arrhythmias might be due to the following mechanisms: i) 3 direct viral damage to myocardial cells and/or conduction system; ii) worsening of pre-4 existing myocardial conditions or conduction disturbances; iii) electrolytic derangements; iv) 5 adrenergic stress leading to electrical instability; and v) ACS with ongoing ischemia.6 The high-grade systemic inflammatory state characteristic of COVID-19 represents 7 another potential important pro-arrhythmic factor that should not be underestimated[44]. 8 Indeed, strong evidence points to inflammation as a novel risk factor for long QT-syndrome 9 and torsades de pointes, primarily via direct electrophysiological effects of cytokines 10 (particularly IL-1, IL-6, and TNF-α) on the myocardium by modulating the expression and/or 11 function of several cardiomyocyte ion (K+ and Ca++) channels[44]. 12 Finally, some therapies proposed for treatment of COVID-19 have been reported to 13 cause arrhythmias[45] (see below and Supplementary Table S1). 14 15 Heart failure and cardiogenic shock 16 Concomitant heart failure was present in 23% to 49% of patients infected with 17 COVID-19[46,47]. Notably, it was associated with worse prognosis as it was almost 5 times 18 more common in patients who did not survive the hospitalization (51.9% vs. 11.7%)[46]. 19 Similar to troponin, elevation of B-type natriuretic peptides (BNP/NT-proBNP) is associated 20 with an unfavorable course among patients with ARDS[31]. 21 In the setting of COVID-19, heart failure could be attributable to either the 22 exacerbation of underlying cardiovascular disease or the new onset of cardiomyopathy 23 (particularly myocarditis or stress cardiomyopathy). Isolated right heart failure can be 24 observed in presence of pulmonary hypertension in the setting of severe ARDS anddiastolic dysfunction. Thus, these patients may be prone to develop 4 pulmonary edema when they are given copious amounts of intravenous fluids to maintain 5 blood pressure or as a vehicle for parenteral drug infusion[24]. However, pulmonary edema as 6 observed in the setting of COVID-19 could also represent the manifestation of a pulmonary 7 vascular injury, which might be direct or mediated by the excess of local angiotensin-2, 8 inducing severe vasoconstriction and microvascular dysfunction, and activating inflammation 9 process[24].

FIGREF20.text: In the context of COVID-19, shock mechanisms could be either exclusively11 distributive (septic) or mixed (distributive and cardiogenic). Cardiogenic shock might be 12 prominent in case of fulminant myocardial involvement. BNP and transthoracic 13 echocardiogram are valuable to guide treatment[24]. Right heart catheterization can also be 14 useful in case of discrepancy of other tests, but at the expense of a higher risk of in-hospital 15 spread of the virus[4]. 16 In patients not responding to conventional management, it is important to determine 17 whether a concomitant cardiogenic component is present, particularly when considering 18 mechanical respiratory and circulatory support with extracorporeal membrane oxygenation 19 (ECMO), as this may impact device selection (venovenous vs. venoarterial)[48] (Figure 3). 20 Initial data in the setting of ARDS due to COVID-19 showed that the prognosis remain poor 21 even with ECMO use (mortality rate 82.3%)[49]. In 12 critically ill COVID-19 patients 22 requiring ECMO, Zeng et al.[50] found that nearly half of them died from septic shock and 23 multiorgan failure. ECMO support duration ranged from 3 to 28 days[50]. A pooled analysis 24 of early reports including 234 ARDS patients, revealed that only 17 (7.2%) received 25 ECMO[51]. The mortality rate was 94.1% in ECMO patients and 70.ELSO) recommends ECMO use only in expert centers in patients with severe ARDS PaO2/FiO2<100) after collegial discussion on a case-by-case basis[52]. ECMO can be 5 considered futile and the patient can be returned to conventional management if no lung or 6 cardiac recovery are observed after 21 days[52].

FIGREF21.text: 19 patients may be at increased risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE). In 10 addition to prolonged immobilization, endothelial damage and vascular inflammation 11 contribute to the development of a hypercoagulable state. In a multicenter Chinese study[53], 12 elevated D-dimer levels (>1 g/l) were an independent predictor of in-hospital death. D-dimer 13 and fibrin degradation products levels were significantly higher in non-survivors. 14 Furthermore, disseminated intravascular coagulation was reported in 71.4% of patients who 15 subsequently died. 16 In a study of 184 patients with severe COVID-19 from three centers in the 17 Netherlands, 31% of patients developed VTE despite pharmacological prophylaxis[54].

FIGREF22.text: Poissy et al.[55] reported a cumulative incidence of pulmonary embolism (PE) of 20.4% (95% 19 confidence interval 13.1%-28.7%) in a cohort of COVID-19 patients in critical conditions. In 20 90.1% of cases, PE occurred in patients already receiving prophylactic antithrombotic 21 treatment. The incidence of PE in this cohort was significantly higher than that observed 22 before the pandemic in patients with different conditions of similar severity or influenza 23infection. Therefore, in case of hemodynamic or respiratory deterioration in a patient with 24 stable parenchymal pulmonary involvement, pulmonary embolism should be suspected.

FIGREF23.text: stratification tools can be used for VTE risk assessment in this setting 4 (e.g. the Caprini, IMPROVE, and Padua models)[56]. Therapeutic anticoagulation, even in 5 absence of obvious VTE complication, could be considered in severely ill patients with high6 D-dimer, although at present this recommendation is not substantiated by solid data[56]. 7 Systemic thrombolysis or catheter-based interventions might be considered in patients with 8 massive PE and hemodynamic compromise. Percutaneous right ventricular assist devices or 9 venovenous ECMO might be contemplated in young patients with right ventricular stroke has been recognized as a complication of severe forms of COVID-14 19[59], which is thought to be associated with the highly prothrombotic state and major 15 endothelial dysfunction caused by the infection. Beyrouti et al.[60] reported a case series of 16 six COVID-19 patients with stroke: large-vessel occlusion with markedly elevated D-dimer 17 levels (≥1000 μg/l) were observed in all patients. Three patients had multiterritory infarcts, 18 two had concurrent VTE, and in two ischemic strokes occurred despite therapeutic 19 anticoagulation[60]. Similarly, Oxley et al.[61] reported on five young COVID-19 patients 20 (age from 33 to 49 years) who presented with large-vessel ischemic stroke. Such an 21 association between large-vessel stroke and COVID-19 in young patients requires further 22 investigation. Therapeutic anticoagulation and thrombolysis could be beneficial to mitigate 23 the consequences of stroke in this setting, but must be balanced against the risk of 24 hemorrhagic transformation, particularly considering the critical conditions of these patients 1 and the delays in diagnosis due to sedation and other concomitant acute issues. emergence of COVID-19 and the psychosocial aspects related to the 5 pandemic have put healthcare systems under pressure with an increasing number of infected 6 individuals, as well as shortage of personal protective equipment (PPE) among healthcare 7 providers, ventilators, and certain drugs.

FIGREF24.text: The following recommendations are proposals to inform clinical decision-making 9 among healthcare providers dealing with cardiovascular patients in the setting of the COVID-10 19 pandemic. These considerations are dynamic and might change in the coming weeks.

FIGREF25.text: of this health crisis has led to cancellation of elective cardiovascular 14 procedures and outpatient visits, due to the concern of disease transmission among healthcare 15 providers and other patients, as well as to optimize resource allocation. Telemedicine is 16 recommended for triage, management of non-emergent conditions, and renewal of 17 prescriptions for chronic stable patients[4]. Any non-essential diagnostic investigation should 18 be deferred. At the same time, it is important to continue guaranteeing care to cardiovascular 19 emergencies, and perform such non-deferrable procedures after collegial discussion on a case-20 by-case basis[4,62,63].

FIGREF26.text: The optimal management strategy for patients with ACS has generated controversy22 during this pandemic period[4,62,63] (Figure 3). In ST-elevation myocardial infarction 23 (STEMI) patients, Chinese providers have developed algorithms that emphasize rapid testing 24 for COVID-19 infection and immediate fibrinolysis, since in their healthcare system the 25 logistics of primary PCI have been severely disrupted by the critical need to protect healthcare 1 providers from contagion[62,64]. The Canadian Association of Interventional Cardiology 2 instead recommends primary PCI in low COVID-19 probability in the absence of major 3 logistic restrictions, while fibrinolysis could be considered in moderate/high probability or 4 COVID-19 positive STEMI patients, particularly in the presence of staff/resource 5 limitations[65]. PCI in catheterization laboratories with aerosol-level PPE should also be 6 considered in case of fibrinolysis contraindication or failure or in cases with cardiogenic 7 shock due to ACS[65]. Even in case of successful initial fibrinolysis, planned PCI should be 8 performed within 24 hours[65]. 9 For non-ST-elevation ACS (NSTE-ACS) patients, medical therapy should be initially 10 pursued. Revascularization should be considered in case of refractory chest pain, malignant 11 arrhythmia and hemodynamic instability, with rapid discharge following 12 revascularization[62,63,65].13 Efforts should be made to differentiate between type 1 and type 2 MI, and other causes 14 of troponin rise[62,63,65]. Diagnostic and interventional procedures should be deferred in 15 patients with type 2 MI, myocardial injury, and patients with suspected myocarditis without 16 cardiogenic shock. Coronary computed tomography angiography, performed at the time of 17 lung evaluation in cases with severe respiratory involvement, might be useful to rule out 18 coronary artery disease. 19 Routine elective cardiac surgery procedures should be rescheduled, while patients at 20 high risk for short-term adverse cardiac events should still be offered surgical treatment[4,66]. 21 Given ICU bed shortages and the risk for in-hospital contagion, medical management as a 22 bridge to intervention after the pandemic should also be considered in selected individuals. 23 The Canadian Society of Cardiac Surgeons have issued detailed recommendations regarding 24 elective and emergency procedures[66].25As the initial peak of the COVID-19 pandemic starts to slowly abate in untreated cardiovascular disease are at increased risk of adverse outcomes and 4 efforts should be made to reestablish prior pathways of care while simultaneously minimizing 5 the risk of COVID-19 resurgence.

FIGREF27.text: -19 may affect delivery of cardiovascular care to non-infected patients8    Little is known about the indirect impact of COVID-19 on cardiovascular outcomes of 9 non-infected individuals. US investigators reported a 38% decrease in cardiac catheterization10 laboratory STEMI activations[68], which is similar to reductions in PCI rates for ACS 11 observed in Italy (32%) and Spain (40%)[69,70]. Emergency medical services from Hong 12 Kong reported a mean increase of ~4 hours in time from symptom onset to first medical 13 contact for STEMI patients[7], presumably because of patient hesitancy in seeking care due to 14 concerns about possible in-hospital COVID-19 contagion. Such delays might have a 15 detrimental impact on prognosis[71]. Previously uncommon mechanical complications of 16 myocardial infarction are now being frequently observed, which could be again due to delays 17 in seeking care[71]. Even more worrisome is the 58% increase in out-of-hospital cardiac 18 arrest observed by Italian investigators during the pandemic, which could reflect the extreme 19 consequences of such medical care avoidance behavior[43]. Finally, further in-hospital delays 20 can be expected among patients admitted to the hospital, which are related to COVID-19 21 infection testing and implementation of precautions for healthcare providers[7].

When performing (or present for) an aerosol-generating procedure (AGP), the 4 provider should wear an N95 mask and a face shield, or a powered air-purifying respirator 5 (PAPR). Additional control measures include limiting the number of healthcare providers to 6 only those essential for patient care during the procedure, and performing AGPs in an 7 airborne infection isolation rooms (with negative air pressure). FIGREF29.text: 19 TREATMENT AND CARDIOVASCULAR IMPLICATIONS13The COVID-19 pandemic has placed the scientific community under extraordinary 14 pressure. The urgent need for a safe and effective treatment can also lead to less rigor and 15 respect of essential research standards as well as relaxed data generation and interpretation,16 which can have undesirable downstream impact[72]. 17 At least 30 clinical trials are currently being conducted to test the efficacy and safety 18 of COVID-19 therapies. Broadly speaking, there are three therapeutic approaches 19 (Supplementary Figure S1): i) antiviral drugs; ii) immune response modulators; and iii) 20 RAAS blockers[73]. A list of the currently investigated drugs, their cardiovascular side 21 effects and potential interactions with cardiovascular medication are detailed in 22 Supplementary Table S1. In this section we will exclusively focus on the cardiovascular side 23 effects and drug interactions of commonly used anti-COVID-19 medications. particularly true with lopinavir-ritonavir (protease inhibitors). Ritonavir is a potent 3 inhibitor of cytochrome P450 (CYP3A). It can increase plasma concentration of class IA and 4 III antiarrhythmics, potentially triggering severe ventricular arrhythmias through QTc 5 prolongation[74]. Similarly, clopidogrel active metabolite concentrations can be reduced, 6 requiring platelet function monitoring to avoid excessive thrombotic risk or switching to 7 prasugrel. Conversely, ticagrelor concentration increases with CYP3A inhibition. With regard 8 to anticoagulants, most direct Xa and IIa inhibitors are also metabolized by CYP3A, and thus 9 there is a potential increase in bleeding risk with ritonavir[75,76]. Besides interactions, 10 lopinavir-ritonavir association can directly cause hypotension and atrioventricular conduction 11 disturbances. 12 Favipiravir is a novel antiviral drug which directly inhibits RNA-dependent-RNA-13 polymerase. It can prolong the QTc interval, increasing the risk for malignant ventricular and hydroxychloroquine (CQ/HCQ) are well known to prolong the QTc 18 interval, which is particularly concerning in COVID-19 patients[45]. These subjects are often 19 hospitalized in critical conditions, and, consequently, predisposed to electrolyte derangements 20 (e.g., hypokalemia), which can act synergistically with CQ/HCQ to prolong the QTc interval, 21 thus triggering ventricular arrhythmias (torsade de pointes). Hypotension and atrioventricular 22 conduction disturbances have also been reported with CQ/HCQ.23 Azithromycin is an antibiotic of the macrolide family. Like CQ/HCQ, azithromycin 24 prolongs the QTc interval. Hence, the frequent association of CQ/HCQ and azithromycin used 25 in COVID-19 patients could increase the risk of torsade de pointes and Methylprednisolone and corticosteroids in general can increase blood pressure and 5 increase fluid retention. They have also been associated with supra-therapeutic INR values of 6 patients on warfarin[80].

FIGREF30.text: Losartan is currently tested in RAAS blockers-naïve COVID-19 patients requiring or10 not requiring hospitalization (NCT04312009 and NCT04311177, respectively), with the 11 rationale that ACE2 downregulation following pulmonary involvement results in angiotensin-12 2 upregulation (angiotensin-2 being a substrate of ACE2), which in turn is assumed to 13 contribute to ARDS pathophysiology[3].14 Following the same rationale, another trial is testing the injection of recombinant 15 soluble ACE2, functioning as a decoy receptor for SARS-CoV-2 virus in patients with 16 evidence COVID-19 viral pneumonia (NCT04287686). The cardiovascular effects of losartan 17 are well known by cardiovascular clinicians but the effects of recombinant ACE2 are 18 unknown. 19 20 INNOVATIVE APPROACHES TO TACKLING CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASE 21 DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC 22 Information technology has the potential to provide useful tools to help tackling the 23 COVID-19 pandemic, specifically to facilitate the early detection of cases (hence optimizing 24 patient workflow within healthcare systems), to disseminate key educational material to the 25 general population and among healthcare providers, and to assist in the diagnosis has recently become a vehicle for fast and massive dissemination of 5 medical content among healthcare professionals. These platforms have been utilized to share 6 protocols to optimize the care of COVID-19 patients and to disseminate information 7 regarding optimal utilization of personal protective equipment to prevent in-hospital 8 dissemination of the virus. Moreover, reports of novel manifestations of COVID-19 infection 9 are actively being shared on social media. For example, the hashtag "#COVIDSTEMI" has 10 recently been used on Twitter by many cardiologists to share cases of patients presenting with 11 electrocardiographic and echocardiographic signs of myocardial infarction, who were 12 subsequently found to have no evidence of obstructive coronary artery disease. This initiative 13 is facilitating the education and awareness of countless healthcare professionals on this new 14 clinical entity, and the organization of these data in peer-reviewed publications. Other 15 initiatives include promoting the scientific debate on the role of RAAS blockers in COVID-19 16 patients and increasing the awareness of the inherent risk of QTc prolongation of CQ/HCQ 17 and azithromycin early during the pandemic[81].

FIGREF31.text: of South Korea has been promoting COVID-19 case tracking and 21 information sharing through smartphone apps early in the course of the pandemic, and this has 22 been considered one of the reasons for the successful containment of the virus in such 23 country. An application under development would let individuals log their movements and 24 compare them with those of known COVID-19 patients, using data supplied by health 25 authorities, in order to identify potential transmissions[82]. FIGREF33.text: 17Patients with cardiovascular disease are particularly vulnerable to COVID-19 and often 18 develop severe forms of the infection. Several cardiovascular manifestations have been 19 observed in COVID-19 patients, including myocardial injury, myocarditis, acute coronary 20 syndromes, pulmonary embolism, stroke, arrhythmias, heart failure, and cardiogenic shock.

FIGREF34.text: 21COVID-19 has profoundly reshaped usual pathways of care of both elective and acute cardiac22 patients. Further research is needed to precisely define the pathophysiology of COVID-19 and 23 to identify and properly evaluate drugs targeting the most relevant mechanisms that 24 characterize severe manifestations of the disease. Collaborative initiatives should harness both 25 conventional and novel tools to provide an effective and timely response to the COVID-19 1 pandemic on the global stage.

Upon TLR activation, cytokines and chemokines are secreted, and the 5 inflammosome is subsequently activated, promoting an inflammatory drive. Excess 6 inflammation is believed to underlie target organ damage in the lung and, eventually, in the 7 cardiovascular system. TABREF0.text: COVID-19 CLINICAL PRESENTATIONSThe spectrum of COVID-19 infection presentations and severity widely vary between individuals[6,15,16] (Table 1). A large study from the Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention revealed that among 72,314 COVID-19 patients, 81.4% had mild symptoms, while severe and critical presentations were only observed in 13.9% and 4.7% of cases, respectively[17]. Mild presentations generally consist of symptoms common to other viral infections ("the flu-like syndrome")[17]. Anosmia and/or dysgeusia have also been reported, particularly in mild presentations[18]. Severe COVID-19 may present as pneumonia, ARDS, with or without distributive and cardiogenic shock[17].CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASE AND COVID-19: VULNERABILITY OF PATIENTSWITH CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASEACE2 represents a key counter regulatory enzyme of the renin-angiotensinaldosterone system (RAAS) that degrades angiotensin II to angiotensin-(1-7), attenuating its effects on vasoconstriction, sodium retention, and fibrosis[3]. After the initial engagement of ACE2 by the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein, there is subsequent down-regulation of ACE2, leading to a reduction of angiotensin-(1-7)[3], which triggers acute lung damage. Importantly, this injury can be attenuated in animal models by blocking the renin-angiotensin pathway with 18 angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEI) or angiotensin II receptor blockers19 (ARB)[19]. Patients with underlying heart disease are among the highest-risk individuals for developing severe forms of the disease, including death[5,17,20,21]. A meta-analysis including 1,527 Chinese patients with COVID-19, reported the following prevalence of hypertension, diabetes, cardiac and cerebrovascular disease: 17.1%, 9.7% and 16.4%, respectively[21]. Comorbidity burden has been associated with the severity of COVID-19 infection and the need for ICU admission[21]. While overall case fatality rate among 44,672 confirmed COVID-19 cases from Wuhan was 2.3%, higher rates were observed in patients with pre-existing cardiovascular disease (10.5%), diabetes (7.3%), and hypertension (6%)[17]. Data from Italy confirmed increased mortality rates in patients with comorbidities, particularly the older adults with pre-existent cardiovascular conditions[22]. Patients with cardiovascular disease are generally older adults. Aging-related immunological quiescence may predispose to higher attack rates in the older adults[23].
